item.title: DealBook: Sanctions or Not, Russian Sway in London May Be Bluster
item.description: Many worry that the global financial center might suffer collateral damage if more penalties are imposed on Russia over its actions in Crimea. But the data suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Rob Stothard for The New York Times

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Clamp Down on Protest Against Chemical Plant in South China
item.description: The demonstration is the latest sign that Chinese citizens are growing increasingly concerned about the environmental risks that come with industrial development.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Leader of China Aims at Military With Graft Case
item.description: The formal accusations against Lt. Gen. Gu Junshan could foreshadow unprecedented criminal prosecutions of other senior military figures in China.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: A People’s Liberation Army guard stands watch at the Bayi Building in Beijing.

item.title: U.S. Is Weighing Release of a Spy for the Israelis
item.description: The United States and Israel are discussing the possible release of Jonathan Pollard, an American serving a life sentence in North Carolina for spying for Israel.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American serving a life term for spying for Israel, seen in 1998.

item.title: Russia Raises Some Salaries and Pensions for Crimeans
item.description: The Kremlin moved to raise pensions and salaries in the annexed territory as the Russian prime minister visited the regional capital.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, right, visited a children's hospital on Monday in Simferopol, the Crimean capital.

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Presidential Campaign Launched on a Bike
item.description: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi was photographed on the campaign trail for the first time since he resigned from the military to run for the presidency, astride a mountain bike. chatting with the public.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: France Overhauls Its Government After Voters Rebuke Socialists
item.description: President François Hollande promised new efforts to revive the economy, including tax cuts, after his party sustained broad losses on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: 3 Jailed Journalists Deny Ties to Brotherhood in Egypt
item.description: Three men who worked for Al Jazeera’s English-language news channel appeared to sway a judge, but their case was suspended and they were sent back to jail.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: U.N. Court Orders Japan to Halt Whaling Off Antarctica
item.description: The International Court of Justice said that Japan’s “scientific whaling” program in the Southern Ocean was illegitimate.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: This photo taken last year by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society shows the Japanese whaling vessel Yushin Maru No. 2 with a minke whale in the Southern Ocean.

item.title: Pakistan’s Ex-Ruler Pleads Not Guilty to Treason Charges
item.description: The formal indictment of Pervez Musharraf is a watershed for Pakistan, where no military ruler has ever been tried for abuse of power.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Supporters of former military ruler Pervez Musharraf protested outside a special court in Islamabad where Musharraf appeared on charges Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Reaction to Far Right’s National Front Wins in French Vote
item.description: The National Front party attained its best result in municipal elections since the late 1990s when it ruled four towns.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Manuel Valls Named as New French Prime Minister
item.description: France’s government has resigned ahead of a reshuffle that comes 24 hours after President Francois Hollande’s Socialists suffered losses in nationwide municipal elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Panel’s Warning on Climate Risk: Worst Is Yet to Come
item.description: A United Nations report warned that climate change is already having sweeping effects and the poorest nations are likely to feel the most severe impacts.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Kadir van Lohuizen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greenland'­s immense ice sheet is melting as a result of climate change.

item.title: Journalists Held by Militants in Syria Reunite With Family
item.description: Javier Espinosa and Ricardo García Vilanova arrived in Madrid a day after Mr. Espinosa called his newspaper to say they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Spanish reporter Javier Espinosa reunited with his son at an airport in Madrid on Sunday.

item.title: Search for Jet Intensifies as Odds Grow Longer
item.description: Australia and Malaysia pledged to press on as 10 planes and 11 ships scoured the latest search area, roughly the size of Poland.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A searcher on an Australian Navy ship on Monday. Australia’s prime minister said he was not considering ending Australian participation in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Converging Interests May Lead to Cooperation Between Israel and Gulf States
item.description: Widespread worry over Iran’s nuclear program and disagreement over American foreign policy have led to a new urgency to find common ground.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Another Worrisome Drop in Euro Zone Inflation
item.description: A rate lower than economists expected adds fire to the debate about whether the euro zone faces a risk of debilitating deflation.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Blast in Kenyan Capital Kills at Least Six
item.description: An explosion in an area of Nairobi that is popular with Somalis, wounded several others on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Lufthansa Warns of Disruptions if Strike Occurs
item.description: The German airline said that the planned three-day strike threatened to affect more than 425,000 passengers across its global network.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 31
item.description: A woman in Mumbai, Maharashtra, celebrating Gudi Padwa, which marks the onset of a new year in the Hindu lunar calendar.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman taking part in a procession celebrating 'Gudi Padwa', which marks the beginning of a new year in the Hindu lunar calendar in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: World Briefing: Rights Group Says Data Suggests Mass Shootings in Nigeria
item.description: Amnesty International said it had satellite images that appeared to show mass graves at a military prison in Nigeria.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Former Israeli Leader Is Convicted of Taking Bribes
item.description: Ehud Olmert, who was prime minister from 2006 to 2009, was accused of accepting money to facilitate the construction of a housing development in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The verdict against Ehud Olmert, center, was the most severe ever against such a senior official in Israel.

item.title: Voices: A Blast and a Wedding
item.description: A Marine deployed twice to Afghanistan found himself fighting once more as a double amputee to reclaim a life of normalcy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.media:description: Jessie Fletcher preparing for patrol in May 2010 in Marja, Afghanistan.

item.title: Lens Blog: Paradise in a Pakistani Valley
item.description: A photographer’s at first puzzling encounter with people displaced from their beloved Swat Valley led him to consider what makes a place paradise.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BORYGA
item.media:description: Lake Mahodand, or Fish Lake, has always been known to the Swatis as a place of breathtaking natural beauty and an abundance of fish. But with the opening of a vehicular road in 2000, the lake has been reduced to a natural theme park for tourists. Aug. 1, 2013.

item.title: Philippines and China in Dispute Over Reef
item.description: China accused the Philippines of illegally occupying its territory after a Philippine vessel resupplied a ship that has been stranded on a tiny reef for 15 years.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The Sierra Madre, a rusted warship that has been grounded on the Second Thomas Shoal since 1999, has been kept in place as a way to reinforce the Philippine claim to the shoal.
